description.en: Free organized parking for motorhomes available in every city in northern Spain. Includes drinking water fill point, toilet waste dump station, and grey water drainage. Usually full but spots can always be found or very nearby.

fullAddress.en: Various cities in Northern Spain

notes.en: Completely free

text.en: In recent days I'm traveling in northern Spain, and to my surprise (assuming you're not surprised) every city has a free organized parking for motorhomes. Includes drinking water fill point, toilet waste dump, and grey water drainage. Usually these spots are quite full, but you can always find a place, or a very close location. This gives a good feeling, and I hope this exists in more countries...
Also very common in Italy and Portugal

description.en: Amazing parking lot that has everything! Cheap, close to train station, perfect base for visiting Amalfi Coast via train, Naples, ancient Roman city of Pompeii, and neighboring Herculaneum. Absolutely brilliant strategy.

fullAddress.en: Pompeii, Campania, Italy (specific location in map link)

notes.en: Cheap parking - contact for exact rates

text.en: I recommend everyone to park in Pompeii - amazing parking lot that has everything! Cheap, close to train, and simply brilliant - every day you take the train to Amalfi line, get off at any city you want along the coast, or jump to Naples. And of course, a must-visit to the Roman city Pompeii and neighboring Roman city Herculaneum - simply a must!!!
We parked there the last two days, definitely recommended and very convenient.
Perfect strategy to avoid Amalfi Coast road restrictions for motorhomes - park here and use train for daily trips
Say hello from Amir, Osnat from Israel and the poodle Ted

text.en: We parked in Lisbon port - free parking with no services at all. We loved it very much. There are other caravans of course, parked right on the water, from the port there's a beautiful promenade and convenient public transportation in the area.

name.en: Morgan Motor Company Factory Tour - Malvern, Wales

description.en: Factory tour of Morgan Motors, a legendary British car manufacturer producing handcrafted sports cars for over 100 years using traditional methods. An experience for all craft lovers - more than 100 years of handwork just like in the old days. Cars are still built by hand with wooden frames and traditional coachbuilding techniques.

fullAddress.en: Morgan Motor Company, Pickersleigh Road, Malvern, Worcestershire, UK

notes.en: Factory tour booking required - check website for pricing

text.en: Today we visited the Morgan Motors factory. An experience for all craft lovers. More than a hundred years of handwork just like in the old days.
This is amazing... a skill that disappeared from the world. Everything today is CNC and laser, but it lacks the character of the curves of old cars, in my opinion.
Book factory tours in advance - this is a working factory with limited visitor access
Located in botanical park area of Wales - good to combine with nature visit

notes.en: Multiple photos shared of handcrafted wooden frames and traditional manufacturing

title.en: Gas System Management and Refilling in Europe

summary.en: Complete guide to managing German gas cylinders (Truma) across Europe, including adapters, refilling locations, and country-specific challenges.

description.en: German cylinders (Truma) use different connections than other European countries. Portugal, France, Italy, and Spain each have their own standards. An 11kg German cylinder typically lasts 5-7 days with heating in winter.

Use iOverlander app - it has a specific category for gas refilling locations. Large campgrounds and motorhome dealerships often know where to refill. In some countries like Portugal, local stations may refuse to refill foreign cylinders, claiming it's illegal.

Purchase a European gas adapter set (available on Amazon.de). These allow refilling your German cylinders at stations with different fittings. Many refilling locations already have adapters, but carrying your own ensures you won't get stuck.

You can purchase a local cylinder with compatible hose that connects to your Truma system in place of the original German hose. This allows using local cylinders, but requires swapping hoses when switching between German and local cylinders.

text.en: NEVER modify or replace the Truma system - it will void your warranty on a new vehicle
Do NOT sleep with gas heating running - even with German systems. Use diesel heater (Webasto) for overnight heating if possible
Set heating to 14-17Â°C, wear a sweater and use a down blanket - gas consumption will improve significantly
Campingaz 907 cylinders (2.8kg) are most common for small motorhomes throughout Europe, but less practical for larger vehicles
Gas cylinder storage compartment must have a drain hole at the bottom. Always leave ventilation when sleeping
Consider installing a CO detector in your motorhome for safety

metadata.author: Multiple contributors: Ilan, Elisha, Ephraim Lior, Oren Kipnis, Rami Galboa

summary.en: Practical advice on managing heating in winter, reducing gas consumption, and staying comfortable without breaking the bank.

description.en: Set heating to 14-17Â°C instead of 23Â°C. While 23Â°C feels comfortable, it drains gas extremely fast - an 11kg cylinder will last only 5-7 days with continuous heating at high temperature.
Wear a sweater and use a down blanket. This is the most cost-effective heating strategy. Add a hot water bottle for extra warmth if needed.
Heat for only 15-20 minutes before bed, not all night. Some travelers wake up mid-night, heat for another 15 minutes, and go back to sleep. This dramatically reduces gas consumption.

title.en: Use Electric Heaters When Plugged In

description.en: When connected to campground electricity, use a household electric heater instead of gas. This saves your gas for wild camping situations.

text.en: Winter gas consumption is normal and expected - don't be alarmed when cylinders empty quickly
Truma water heaters also heat water passively, so you don't need to actively run water heating - keep it on OFF

title.en: Generator vs Battery Systems for Motorhomes

summary.en: Comprehensive comparison of generators versus lithium battery systems for off-grid power in European motorhome travel. Covers practicality, safety, costs, and recommendations.

description.en: Generators are rarely used in Europe for motorhomes. Managing power with a generator is cumbersome: requires significant gasoline storage (smell and safety issues), cannot keep refrigerator on 12V mode, guarantees noise for you and neighbors, similar cost to battery alternative.

At similar cost to a generator, purchase 100Ah lithium battery. Can last several days without charging, assuming refrigerator runs on gas and no other heavy consumers. For Fiat Ducato: two 100Ah LiFePO4 batteries fit under driver's seat, or one 150Ah battery (likely possible for Ford as well).

First identify what you want to power: Refrigerator/heating? Use gas (excellent solution). Lighting? Usually not the problem. Air conditioning? May need stronger generator. Understanding your needs determines the solution.

text.en: Gasoline storage for generator creates smell and safety risks
Generator noise will disturb both you and surrounding campers
LiFePO4 batteries last longer and are safer than traditional lithium batteries
Generator quickly becomes more hassle than benefit in European camping

summary.en: Guide to obtaining Portuguese and German citizenship for extended European travel. Covers benefits, processes, timelines, and current challenges.

description.en: European citizenship allows staying in Europe longer than 3 months. Fast track through airport queues. Additional benefits vary by country (German citizenship particularly advantageous). PRIORITY: Get ID and passport first, then explore other benefits.

THE PARTY IS OVER. After Abramovich oligarch got passport in one week, requirements severely tightened. NOW: Only descendants of expelled Jews who can prove connection absolutely. New requirements: Portuguese language test, Portuguese history test, additional strict criteria making it nearly impossible. Applications stuck for 3+ years without progress. Law firms charging money but ultimately updating there's no possibility. SOME STILL SUCCEED but process takes 3.5+ years.

Timeline: Applied online 2.5 years ago, submitted documents to embassy 1.5 years ago, approved 2 weeks ago (total ~2.5 years). NO LAWYER NEEDED except for notary approval of photocopied documents. More straightforward than Portuguese process currently.

text.en: Portuguese citizenship: Be very cautious of law firms promising results - many charge fees then report impossibility
Once approved: Immediately get ID and passport before exploring other benefits
German citizenship particularly beneficial - multiple advantages
Portuguese applications currently stuck 3+ years - manage expectations

summary.en: Comprehensive guide to traveling Morocco with a motorhome, including SIM cards, costs, border crossing, camping, and safety tips from experienced travelers.

description.en: Entry from Tarifa, Spain to Tangier, Morocco by ferry costs approximately 280 EUR for one person with motorhome. Border inspection occurs on the ferry. Passport is stamped, vehicle papers checked upon arrival in Tangier. International driver's license and vehicle insurance (Green Card or ADAC full insurance) required.
Local SIM card (Maroc Telecom) costs 20 dirhams (2 EUR). Load 200 dirhams for 30GB data and 100 dirhams for calls - total approximately 15-17 EUR for full connectivity.

Morocco has many motorhome parking areas, most are good and provide all necessary services. Very affordable - breakfast with egg, tomatoes, cheese, butter, fresh Moroccan bread, and coffee at a modern cafe in Agadir costs only 20 dirhams (2 EUR).

Heavy enforcement in desert areas. Police often position at speed limit transitions (80 to 60 km/h). Fines are official with printed forms: 150 dirhams (~15 EUR) for 8-12 km/h over limit. Speed limit signs before junctions/villages are serious. Drive with cruise control slightly under the limit.

Moroccan people are very friendly. Historical Jewish heritage sites exist, including ancient synagogue (now Jewish museum) in Ouarzazate. Gas stations are plentiful. Eastern/southeastern Morocco landscapes resemble Arava desert with occasional mud villages.

text.en: Use Portuguese or other EU passport if available - Israeli travelers using non-Israeli documents report smooth entry
When mentioning Israeli identity in casual conversations, responses are consistently positive - Moroccans have historical sympathy for Jews
Take your time - embrace the desert pace, don't rush through Morocco
Speed limit signs before intersections/villages are always serious even if they don't appear necessary

summary.en: How to use Polarsteps app to automatically track your motorhome journey with photos and maps, completely free with no ads.

description.en: Download Polarsteps app (completely free with no ads). Set start and end dates for your trip. The app runs in the background automatically tracking your route.
Every day or every few days, open the app and add photos at the location you want on the map. Everything is saved permanently.
Generate shareable links to your trip that others can follow. All your trips are saved since you started using the app - data from 2019 onwards is preserved.

text.en: App is extremely easy to use - just set dates and it works in the background
All your historical trips remain accessible - great for reminiscing and sharing travel stories

summary.en: Critical safety protocols for reversing large motorhomes, including spotter positioning, walkie-talkie use, and why cameras alone are insufficient.

description.en: Cameras (even 8K) do not provide correct proportions and cannot show the entire space - trees, obstacles, vehicles, etc. This is a recipe for disaster. Best case: body damage. Worst case: bodily injury.

IRON RULE: When driving a large vehicle without rear visibility, you MUST ensure there is a spotter on the left side of the vehicle, positioned so the driver can maintain eye contact through the left mirror.

Best practice: Use small walkie-talkies with partner on the ground behind vehicle who can see everything and give instructions. Alternative: Direction with hand signals through side mirrors. This is also the ultimate test of perfect partnership.

text.en: Without a spotter - recipe for disaster. Best case: sheet metal damage; worst case: bodily injury.
The worst the situation the better the story! Every setback is the beginning of rescue, meeting good people, and an unforgettable event.

title.en: Starlink Internet for Motorhomes - Complete Guide

summary.en: Comprehensive guide to using Starlink satellite internet in motorhomes, including cost comparison between plans, data caps, and when it's worth the investment.

description.en:
Three main options:

1. Mini 50GB Plan: ~50-55 USD/month, 50GB data cap, cannot add more data mid-cycle
2. Mini Unlimited: ~79 CAD/month (~60 USD), unlimited data
3. Standard Unlimited: ~165 USD/month, unlimited data, better performance

Equipment costs: Mini ~500 USD new, Standard ~360 USD

Typical family traveling usage: Maximum 34GB/month even with downloading movies and frequent video calls home. 50GB plan is generally sufficient for most travelers if used reasonably. Cellular data can supplement when 50GB runs out.

165 USD/month is very expensive, especially when most of the time you can browse using cellular at laughably low costs. The 50-55 USD/month plan sounds more logical. In countries with poor cellular coverage, Starlink is worthwhile. In countries with cellular everywhere, buying a huge cellular data package is significantly cheaper.

The problem is when you get stuck without cellular browsing in some remote hole (fairly rare), then you curse and get frustrated that you don't have Starlink. Forest coverage and tree obstructions can also block Starlink signal, requiring finding a clearing.

text.en: Terms can change if you move to another country for extended period - they may switch you to that country's pricing
Before spreading salt on Starlink purchase decision, consider: will you be in remote areas frequently? Is cellular reliable in your travel region?
Tree coverage can block Starlink signal - may need to move to a clearing for reliable connection

title.en: Amalfi Coast Access Strategy for Motorhomes

summary.en: How to visit Amalfi Coast with motorhome restrictions - parking in Pompeii and using train for daily coastal trips. Includes regulations and practical advice.

description.en: Motorhomes (especially 7.3m+) are not allowed to enter the coastal road during daytime. Locals strictly enforce no-entry ban for motorhomes on the coast-adjacent road. Police ticket violators. Width restriction is 2.20m. Other roads in the area have no problem.

Park at Parcheggio Pompei Zone - cheap, has everything, close to train station. From there, take daily train rides to Amalfi line, getting off at any coastal city you want, or visit Naples. Perfect base strategy.
Some travelers park at overnight campground the evening before and do the coastal drive with a rental car. This allows flexibility to stop anywhere along the coast.

title.en: Double Tire (Dual Wheels) Pros and Cons

title.en: Navigation Apps for Large Motorhomes - Height and Weight Restrictions

summary.en: Comprehensive guide to navigation apps that account for motorhome dimensions, height restrictions, and weight limits. Includes comparisons, recommendations, and safety considerations for large vehicles in Europe.

title.en: The Problem with Standard Navigation Apps

description.en: Waze and Google Maps do NOT have options for tall vehicles. They will direct you to narrow roads, low bridges, and restricted areas. In England, there are many narrow roads and low passages that won't appear on Google Maps. This is extremely dangerous for motorhomes, especially those 10+ tons, 3.85m height, or large 4x4 vehicles.

Sygic Truck is highly recommended by experienced travelers. You can input your motorhome dimensions (height is critical). Navigate with TWO apps simultaneously: Waze + Sygic. Compare travel times and routes. Give priority to Sygic because your motorhome dimensions are entered there. One user learned this lesson after arriving at a low railway bridge that forced them to backtrack, which led them to purchase this app.

title.en: Alternative: Snooper GPS - Premium Dedicated Device

description.en: Snooper is a specialized navigation app for caravans. â‚¬350 for lifetime license. Also has modules for buses and trucks of all sizes. It's a French product specifically designed for motorhomes. Includes offline maps capability which is a significant advantage. One-time payment allows 3 version updates per year and unlimited map downloads by country.

Park4night is the essential app for finding: (a) Water refill points, (b) Grey water disposal, (c) Cassette toilet emptying stations, (d) Hiking trail starting points where you can park, (e) Navigation that recognizes weight and height restrictions (for trucks/large motorhomes). This was recommended when someone asked about apps for a 10-ton, 3.85m height, fully independent 4x4 truck conversion.
CamperContact is an excellent app for finding parking locations. Recommended by experienced travelers as their favorite parking app.

Best practice: Navigate with two navigation apps simultaneously (usually Waze and Sygic). Compare times and routes. Give priority to Sygic since motorhome dimensions are entered there. This cross-referencing strategy helps avoid dangerous situations. In England, during two weeks of travel, one user had to make many detours after Waze directed them to forbidden or impossible locations.

text.en: NEVER rely solely on Waze or Google Maps for large motorhomes - they don't account for height restrictions
Always input your motorhome dimensions accurately - height is the most critical
Download offline maps before traveling to areas with poor connectivity
There are no reliable free apps for truck navigation - paid solutions like Sygic or Snooper are worth the investment
Companies like Concord provide truck navigation software professionally

title.en: Long-Term Motorhome Storage Guide - Winter and Extended Periods

summary.en: Comprehensive 14-step checklist for storing motorhome for months during winter or extended periods. Covers water systems, fuel, tires, batteries, pest prevention, and more.

name.en: IKEA storage boxes with masking tape

title.en: Empty All Water Tanks and Boiler

description.en: 1. Empty all water tanks and leave caps, drain plugs, and faucets open (prevents pipe burst from freezing). Including emptying the Truma boiler. This is critical in winter climates to prevent pipe and tank damage from freezing water expansion.

2. 1/4 tank diesel (adding fresh diesel will refresh old diesel). Alternative opinion: Full tank is better - this minimizes moisture condensation. Moisture accumulation leads to water in fuel system despite separators. Fuel system components are very expensive. Diesel doesn't spoil quickly, and it doesn't freeze around minus 20Â°C. Full tank is the consensus recommendation to prevent condensation.
3. Inflate tires above normal (prevents tire 'squaring' or flat-spotting from sitting in one position for months).
4. Cassette washed, empty, and left open (prevents odors and seal damage).
5. Refrigerator left open (prevents mold and odors).

6. Don't leave a drop of food - everything donated (prevents pests). Some people leave unopened rice and pasta bags. Oil and vinegar bottles can be left. Once in 13 years of traveling, mice entered - they preferred dry food and paper towels, didn't touch electrical wiring.
7. Bedding and clothes - washed, scented, and sealed in IKEA boxes with masking tape (prevents moisture, pests, and odors).

8. Disconnect rear and front batteries physically at the terminals. Also disconnect from solar controller - the cables coming from the panel. Wrap with electrical tape and clearly mark which is plus and which is minus. This prevents parasitic drain over months of storage.
9. Disconnect all electrical panel (move breakers to disconnected). This ensures no parasitic drain on any systems.

10. If possible - battery on charging (didn't happen to me, except twice). In places that freeze in winter, move batteries to warm room. Cold temperatures dramatically reduce battery capacity and can damage batteries.
11. Gas - 2 cylinders closed, leave note on active cylinder with estimated quantity remaining. This helps you know fuel status when you return.
12. Close curtains (protects interior from UV damage and provides privacy/security).
13. Key and registration with whoever I parked with/near, and spare set flies with me. Never leave yourself without access to vehicle documents.
14. Rear air bags/cushions at normal pressure - check before movement to know how much leaked. This helps identify potential leaks before hitting the road.

text.en: Mouse poison is risky - mice can enter electrical wiring channels where poison can't reach. Use traps instead.
One user stored for half a year in winter weather (heavy rain, some snow) successfully using this checklist
Solar panels can be left connected to charge batteries during storage if you have a reliable solar controller
Full fuel tank is universally recommended - prevents moisture condensation which is worse than old diesel
This recommendation is known to sailors and is even tested in seamanship exams

title.en: Emergency Preparedness - Lessons from Spanish Power Outage

summary.en: Real-world lessons learned during massive power outage in Spain/Portugal/France. Covers cash reserves, food/water minimums, offline navigation, and motorhome self-sufficiency.

description.en: On April 29, 2025, a massive power outage hit Spain/Portugal/France. Communication networks failed completely. Waze continued to navigate, but without using satellites (offline mode). Gas stations had enormous queues or no fuel. After sampling 5 stations, found one with fuel - 'cash only'. We refueled and calmed down. No navigation and no Park4night, but we found our way to Malaga (which was closer than Seville), where we found an improvised parking lot on the beach.
Never be without cash. During power outages, credit cards don't work and ATMs are offline. Cash is emergency-mandatory always. During this incident, only cash-accepting gas stations could operate.

title.en: Essential Lesson 2: Minimum Food and Water Base

description.en: Need minimum base of drinking water, don't have to have everything full/empty. The fridge was full but water was borderline, and we didn't have enough fuel to reach Seville. Fortunately, lamb ribs weren't affected by the power outage, and neither was Dorit's mythological rice. Keep minimum reserves - doesn't need to be full, but basic emergency supplies are essential.
Download maps to phone for offline navigation. Waze worked without satellites, but having dedicated offline maps is crucial. This was pointed out correctly by user's wife Dorit.

Different approaches exist: (1) Always keep tank as full as possible - fill whenever you can even if not empty. Learned from motorcycle trips - refuel even with 3/4 tank. (2) Alternative view: Fill and empty daily is excessive ('not squadron commander mode'). Personal choice, but for some days at least, have minimum water and fuel reserves. Suggestion: 5 liters bottled water is sufficient for emergency.
Depends on tank sizes. As general rule, aim to have water and fuel reserves for at least a few days. Balance between being prepared and being obsessive.

text.en: Major infrastructure failures can happen - Spain/Portugal/France massive outage proved this
Motorhome self-sufficiency is an advantage during infrastructure failures
Warning signs exist - stay alert to developing situations
This was a learning experience - 'another experience' as the original poster called it

title.en: Flexible vs Rigid - Roof Structure Dependency

description.en: Depends mainly on roof structure. Rigid panels are generally preferred when roof can support them, but flexible panels are necessary for curved or weak roofs.

One user planned to look for installers in Bad Kissingen (Germany) in a few months. Motorhome centers and specialized workshops can perform installations. Research local options in area where you'll be traveling.

text.en: Solar installation is highly customized - one size does not fit all
Plan system voltage (12V/24V/48V) early - affects all component choices
Consider future expansion - easier to oversize controller now than replace later

title.en: France Toll Road Navigation and Cost Avoidance

summary.en: Essential strategies for avoiding expensive toll roads in France, understanding motorhome classifications, and using Google Maps to bypass toll stations.

name.en: Google Maps or similar navigation app

description.en: France toll road rules differ from rest of Europe and can be extremely expensive. You may need a mortgage bank at the toll booth! Critical thresholds: over 3.5 tons actual weight (some roads have weight stations), over 3 meters height (laser detector), over 6 meters length = you pay like a truck.

Navigate with Google Maps and select 'Avoid Toll Roads' option. Google will take you off the highway at the exit before the toll station, and bring you back on at the exit after it. This effectively bypasses the toll while staying on main routes.
France has strict speed enforcement. Speed camera fines are approximately 80 EUR even for minor violations (few km/h over limit). Use speed camera warning apps to avoid fines.

text.en: Be very careful about speed limits in France - cameras are strict and fines add up quickly
If your motorhome is under 6m length, under 3m height, and under 3.5 tons, you'll pay car rates instead of truck rates

title.en: Canola (Rapeseed) Fields in Europe - Agricultural Information

summary.en: Comprehensive information about the bright yellow canola/rapeseed fields you'll see throughout Europe in spring, including agricultural uses and benefits.

description.en: The bright yellow fields visible throughout Europe (especially Cambridge area and northern regions) are canola/rapeseed in bloom. This is the flowering season for this amazing plant that serves multiple agricultural purposes.

Mustard/Canola serves many purposes: 1) Condiment production - seeds used to make popular sauces throughout Europe (especially France, Germany, England). 2) Spice - whole or ground seeds used in dishes and preserves. 3) Folk medicine - used for respiratory problems, muscle pain, external heat treatments. 4) Green manure - organic farming uses it as cover crop to enrich soil with nitrogen and suppress weeds. 5) Biodiesel oil production - for industrial and sometimes culinary use. 6) Bee pasture - attracts bees for pollination and honey production. In summary: an amazing crop where every part of the plant is used.

text.en: Spring (April-May) is the best time to see these spectacular yellow fields across Europe

title.en: Sygic Truck Navigation for Large Motorhomes - Complete Setup Guide

summary.en: Comprehensive guide to using Sygic Truck navigation app for motorhomes over 3.5 tons, including premium subscription costs, vehicle profile configuration, map downloads, and real-world usage feedback.

description.en: COST: Approximately $44 USD one-time payment (lifetime). FEATURES LOCKED BEHIND PREMIUM: Vehicle dimension configuration (height, weight, length). Route optimization based on vehicle profile. Map downloads (no additional cost for maps). TRIAL: Free trial available for several days to test before purchasing.

Configure vehicle as CAMPER (not truck). Set exact dimensions: Height (e.g., 3.9m), Weight (e.g., 10 tons), Length (e.g., 6-10m). Set maximum speed appropriate for vehicle. Choose route preference: Local roads (more scenic, suitable for slower vehicles) vs Highways. Example configuration from user: 3.9m height, 10 tons weight, camper type, local roads preference.

After purchasing premium subscription: Europe maps available for download at no additional cost. Download maps for regions you plan to travel. Offline navigation capability once maps downloaded. Users report successfully downloading European maps without extra charges.

POSITIVE FEEDBACK: Does NOT route through roads too narrow. Avoids bridges with height/weight restrictions that would block passage. Avoids roads with physical limitations. Successfully tested by multiple users. ISSUES ENCOUNTERED: May route through areas with 7.5 ton weight limit signs (legal for motorhomes registered as campers, not commercial trucks). Does not prevent entry to such zones if motorhome registration allows it. COMPARISON TO GOOGLE/WAZE: Google and Waze caused multiple issues: Routed to locations with height/weight restrictions, Led to very narrow roads (beautiful but problematic when meeting oncoming traffic). Sygic avoided these problems.

7.5 TON ZONE ROUTING: App may route through areas marked with 7.5 ton weight limits. This is LEGAL for motorhomes registered as campers (different regulations than commercial trucks). Not a routing error - motorhomes have different weight restriction rules. VEHICLE REGISTRATION MATTERS: If registered as CAMPER/MOTORHOME: Different weight rules apply, 7.5 ton zones usually accessible. If registered as TRUCK: Must respect commercial vehicle weight limits. RECOMMENDATION: Register vehicle as camper in app settings, not truck.

text.en: Use free trial period to test app before purchasing $44 lifetime subscription
Configure as CAMPER not truck - different routing rules apply
Choose local roads preference for more scenic routes suitable for slower vehicles
7.5 ton zone routing is normal if registered as camper - not an error
Maps are included in premium price - no additional costs for Europe downloads
Much better than Google/Waze for large motorhomes - avoids physical restrictions

title.en: OBD2 Diagnostic Scanner for Motorhome Troubleshooting

summary.en: Guide to using OBD2 diagnostic scanners for motorhome troubleshooting. Helps identify issues immediately, guide mechanics, or perform temporary self-repairs. Essential tool for all motorhome owners.

name.en: OBD2 scanner device (e.g., Ancel AS500 or similar)
OBD2 port access in vehicle (standard location under dashboard)

description.en: OBD2 (On-Board Diagnostics) scanner is a device that reads error codes from your vehicle's computer system. When issues occur, you immediately know what the problem is. Can guide mechanics on exact issue to fix. Allows temporary self-repair in some cases. Useful for instructing mechanics or performing DIY fixes.

ANCEL AS500 OBD2 SCANNER: Price: ~165 ILS (~$45 USD). Automatically identifies vehicle. Points to source of problem. Engine fault code reader. Lifetime free updates. Available on AliExpress and other retailers. COMPATIBILITY: Works with Fiat from 2006 onwards. OBD2 standard introduced around 1995, but not all generic scanners work with all vehicles. Check compatibility with seller before purchase.

IMMEDIATE ISSUE DIAGNOSIS: When warning lights appear. When vehicle behavior changes unexpectedly. Before calling mechanic (know the issue first). PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE: Check for pending error codes. Monitor vehicle health. Verify repair success after mechanic work. COST SAVINGS: Avoid diagnostic fees at mechanics. Prevent being overcharged for wrong repairs. DIY temporary fixes when possible.

ITALY BREAKDOWN INCIDENT (May 2025): SITUATION: Fiat Ducato motorhome (5 years old, 30K km) broke down three times in a row near Florence-Lucca-Pistoia area. First repair: Transmission warning light, couldn't shift gears - software update performed. Second repair: Wouldn't move - fuel pump sensor replaced. Third breakdown: Engine died while driving, wouldn't restart - cause unknown. RESOLUTION: Ron Kellner contacted user, helped coordinate professional mechanic assistance. Demonstrates importance of having OBD2 scanner to immediately identify recurring issues and avoid multiple incorrect repairs.

text.en: Worth every penny - low financial risk compared to benefits of immediate diagnosis
Keep scanner in each family vehicle - not just motorhome
Not all generic scanners work with all vehicles - verify compatibility before purchase
Check with seller if product is compatible with your specific vehicle model and year

title.en: Schengen Visa Rules for Israeli Citizens - 90/180 Day Rule

summary.en: Comprehensive guide to Schengen visa regulations for Israeli travelers, including 90/180 day rule, countries covered, exceptions, digital nomad visa options, and enforcement.

description.en: Israelis can stay in Schengen countries without visa for up to 3 months (90 days). After this, they must leave Schengen countries for at least 3 months. Then they can return for another maximum of 3 months. Maximum stay is 6 months per year: 3 months consecutive and 3 month break required.

The Schengen system checks 180 days backwards at any given moment. Simply crossing to non-Schengen countries (England, Gibraltar, Switzerland) every 3 months is NOT sufficient. Use the ninety180.com website to enter every entry and exit - it shows your remaining balance. Essential for trip planning.

EU Schengen members (25 of 27): Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria (joined fully Jan 1 2025), Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania (joined fully Jan 1 2025), Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden. Non-EU Schengen members: Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Switzerland. NOT in Schengen: Cyprus, Ireland. Cyprus is planning to join Schengen in the future but as of 2025 is not part of it.

Can be applied for through consulate - takes time. Required documents vary slightly between countries. Entry to EU according to the country from which visa was received. Can be approved for those with Israeli citizenship only. Important note: Switzerland is part of Schengen agreement even though not EU member.

Can apply for digital nomad visa, but comes with clear requirements: Monthly income of at least 13,000 ILS from country of origin, valid medical insurance for one year in the country where applying for visa, presentation of rental contract or proof of property ownership. Very important: not recommended to exceed the allowed 3-month stay period. Exceeding can lead to fines, registration in system, deportation from country, and even future entry ban to Schengen area or other countries.

All Schengen countries are synchronized with each other, even those that are not EU members like Norway, Switzerland, and Iceland. There's no point trying to move between countries to reset the count - everything is documented and accessible to all member countries of the agreement. Those living as digital nomad must plan route in advance, operate according to rules, and live with peace of mind. Don't play with fire.

text.en: Use ninety180.com to track your Schengen days - essential tool for planning
Overstaying leads to serious consequences: fines, deportation, future entry bans
Simply crossing to non-Schengen countries every 3 months doesn't reset the count - it's a 180-day rolling window

metadata.author: Ron Kellner, Oren Kipnis, Amir Meltzer, Sylvie

notes.en: Updated with Bulgaria and Romania full Schengen membership as of Jan 1, 2025. Information verified by multiple experienced travelers.

title.en: Windshield Crack Management - When to Replace vs Wait

summary.en: Expert guidance on managing windshield cracks in motorhomes, including when to replace immediately vs waiting until inspection test, cost considerations, and understanding dynamic vs static cracks.

description.en: Need to distinguish between static cracks that don't develop further versus dynamic cracks that develop over time and at some stage could present interference and even risk of windshield disintegration when there are sudden temperature differences. Therefore in any case, until replacement, monitor it - mark a point/points on the edge/edges and see if it's progressing.

If the crack is not serious, it's a waste to repair it until the test because it might happen again and again - you pay deductible and sometimes higher. Replace before the test and that's it. Very common on European roads - if crack isn't terrible, wait until test and save the next crack plus 150 EUR deductible. The rush is from the devil (patience recommended for test in November 2026).

Two known factors for cracks: 1) Something hitting the windshield. 2) Development of rust in the window frame that applies pressure on the windshield. Ron raised another point - if there was a small impact on the windshield before storage, temperature changes can cause the crack to expand. Small impacts before storage that aren't visible can develop into larger cracks due to temperature differences during storage period.

There is no advantage to replacement at Ford except reducing your bank account. From experience they charge double and more for the windshield and work, and also keep you longer with them. Go to a serious glass repair shop and make sure they order you an appropriate windshield. Anyway the chance this will happen again is not negligible.

text.en: Mark the crack edges and monitor for progression - this helps determine if it's static or dynamic
Waiting until test date can save deductible (150 EUR) plus avoid paying twice if another crack occurs
Temperature differences during storage can expand small unnoticed cracks - inspect carefully before and after storage

title.en: Diesel Fuel Injection Pump Air Leak Troubleshooting

summary.en: Complete troubleshooting guide for diesel fuel injection pump air leaks causing engine power loss and repeated air lock issues. Includes bleeding procedures, finding air entry points, and sealing methods.

name.en: PTFE tape or liquid thread sealant

description.en: Symptoms include: loss of power, engine dies on uphill climbs, successful bleeding but problem returns after 5 minutes on next climb. This indicates continuous air entry into fuel system rather than one-time air lock.

Look for where the pump is drawing air. Check all connections, fittings, and hoses in the fuel line between tank and injection pump. Working since yesterday evening trying to find the source. Sealed one suspicious connector but it didn't help - continue searching systematically.

At the top of the diesel pump there is a round 'button' - it's meant to bleed air from the system. Press it several times, like a pump action. Try this procedure - it usually helps (unless there's constant air entry from another location). Located on upper part of fuel injection pump.

Recommended sealing with: 1) Specialized liquid gasket for chemical and fuel resistance - like Permatex Fuel Resistant Gasket Maker or equivalent. 2) PTFE (Teflon) liquid or tape, if it's a threaded connection. 3) Epoxy or polyurethane-based sealing compounds designated for fuel contact (check 'fuel resistant' on packaging). Temporary solution: isolation tape while in middle of nowhere - seal with what you have available. May also have Teflon tape if you decide to open threaded connections.

Regarding fuel resistance: We had an explosion in diesel tank that we sealed with soap paste. It holds until today although you need to renew it occasionally. This is a field-tested emergency solution that has proven effective for temporary repairs until proper professional repair can be done.

Don't forget to check the fuel filters as potential source of air entry. Clogged or improperly sealed filters can allow air into the system. This was suggested as potential cause during troubleshooting discussion.

text.en: If bleeding works but problem returns quickly (5 minutes), there is ongoing air entry - keep searching for leak source
Work systematically - seal one suspected connection at a time and test before moving to next
Emergency temporary sealing can be done with isolation tape or soap paste until proper fuel-resistant sealant available

title.en: German Vehicle Registration for Non-Residents - Legal Method

summary.en: Complete guide to legally registering a motorhome in Germany as a non-resident using German law that allows using a German resident's address for mail forwarding. Includes process, requirements, and testing obligations.

name.en: German resident willing to receive mail

description.en: In Germany there is a possibility using German law that allows use of a German resident's address - the resident signs that they commit to receive your mail and forward it to you. There's an online form you download, sign, and attach passport copies, and it works. Authorities recognize the address as your German address. Completely legal! The trick was discovered by Tom Lerner from the group, and as far as known, I am the second who purchased a vehicle in Germany with this arrangement.

The vehicle I purchased is with permanent German registration (not temporary) in my name. Download online form, have German resident sign commitment to receive and forward mail, attach passport copy, submit to authorities. This creates legal German address for vehicle registration purposes.
This requires TÃœV test once every two years in Germany. Haven't checked, but might be possible in other EU countries as well. The test must be conducted to maintain registration validity.
France also has a similar solution - you can register in your name. The process exists in France as well for non-resident vehicle registration.

text.en: This is a completely legal method recognized by German authorities - not a workaround or grey area
Contact Tom Lerner from the community for detailed guidance - he pioneered this method
Must find trustworthy German resident willing to receive and forward official mail - this is critical
Plan for TÃœV testing every 2 years - requires bringing vehicle to Germany (or possibly other EU countries)

notes.en: Pioneer: Tom Lerner. Second person to use method: Ilan. Confirmed working method with permanent registration.

title.en: European Motorhome Ownership Options for Foreigners

summary.en: Overview of different legal methods to own and register motorhomes in Europe as non-EU residents, including Germany's address system, France's options, and US LLC comparison.

description.en: Question related to ownership (through a friend), not familiar with Europe but for those without a close local friend, is there still an option to buy a motorhome as a foreign citizen? In the US it's only possible in a small part of states, and there are also ways to bypass this through registering the vehicle under an LLC business name.

In Germany there is a possibility using German law that allows use of resident's address with signed form committing them to receive and forward your mail. You download online form, sign, attach passport copies, and it works. The authorities recognize the address as your German address. Completely legal to the letter of the law! Vehicle purchased this way is with permanent German registration (not temporary) in your name.
France also has a similar solution - registration in your name is possible. The process exists for non-residents as well.

text.en: Unlike US LLC method which is a workaround, European methods are direct legal pathways recognized by authorities
Both Germany and France require some form of local address connection - either through resident friend or legal service

title.en: Mercedes Sprinter 4x4 vs 2x4: Choosing the Right Motorhome Drivetrain

summary.en: Comprehensive comparison of 4x4 versus 2x4 motorhomes for different travel styles. Covers when 4x4 is necessary, cost differences, and suitability for various destinations including Europe, Morocco, and off-grid travel.

en: **When 4x4 is Beneficial:**
- Off-grid and remote area access
- Moderate to challenging terrain (gravel, mud, snow)
- Africa and developing countries with poor roads
- Mountain passes and rural trails in Spain, France
- Prevents getting stuck in wet grass or soft ground
- Opens up more route possibilities even in Europe
**When 2x4 is Sufficient:**
- Primary travel on paved roads and highways
- Urban and rural areas with good infrastructure
- Most of Europe, including northern Spain, Italy, Poland
- Morocco standard routes (one month tested successfully)
- Easy trails similar to "KKL" style paths
- Budget-conscious travelers prioritizing newer vehicles
**4x4 Technical Requirements:**
- True 4x4 with at least center and rear diff locks (not AWD)
- Tire size: 245/75R17 or larger recommended
- AWD (sold in America) only suitable for snow/light trails
- Consider having Unimog for recoveries on extreme terrain
**Cost Considerations:**
- 4x4 significantly more expensive than 2x4
- 4x4 often means older vehicle vs newer 2x4 at same price
- Example: 2023 2x4 for â‚¬50K vs older 4x4 at same price
- Newer vehicle benefits: better fuel economy, reliability, features
**Vehicle Options:**
- **Mercedes Sprinter 4x4**: Premium European option
- **Ford/Chevrolet 4x4**: American builds with slide-outs available
- **Iveco 4x4**: Popular for serious off-grid
- **Vario 818 4x4**: Slow but goes everywhere
- **Toyota Land Cruiser Troopy**: Excellent off-road base (small for motorhome)
**Real User Experiences:**
- "Most of our travels are on roads or easy trails. 2x4 is perfect."
- "Spent month in Morocco with 2x4, everything excellent."
- "Small rural roads are amazing, meet more locals than highways."
- "At our age, not worth investing in 4x4 unless going beyond dense European road network."
- "4x4 opens many options, even in Spain. Prevents embarrassment of getting stuck on wet grass."
**Recommendations by Destination:**
- **Europe (on-road):** 2x4 sufficient
- **Europe (off-road enthusiast):** 4x4 recommended
- **Morocco standard routes:** 2x4 works fine
- **Africa/Tanzania/serious overland:** 4x4 essential
- **Mountain regions (Alps, Pyrenees):** 2x4 OK for paved, 4x4 for trails
**Resources:**
- Outside Van (custom Sprinter builds): https://outsidevan.com/vans-for-sale/

guides.sharedBy: Rami Galboa, Ilan, Boaz Gutman, Amir Meltzer, Tuval Avishi

title.en: Building the Fully Autonomous Motorhome: Essential Equipment Guide

summary.en: Guide to outfitting a motorhome for complete autonomy (off-grid capability) with all modern comforts. Covers purchasing strategy, budget breakdown, and essential equipment for extended travel without hookups.

en: **Purchasing Strategy:**
- Buy new motorhome as base vehicle for reliability
- Budget for comprehensive equipment upgrades
- Example budget breakdown:
- New motorhome: â‚¬117,000
- Equipment and upgrades: â‚¬30,000
**Vehicle Size Philosophy:**
- "Not too big, not too small - perfect for couple"
- Occasional guest capacity (another couple)
- Economical and reliable operation
- Balance between comfort and maneuverability
**Essential Autonomy Equipment:**
- Solar power system
- Large battery bank (lithium recommended)
- Fresh water capacity (large tanks)
- Grey and black water tanks (extended capacity)
- Efficient heating system
- 12V appliances
- Inverter for AC power needs
**Mobility Add-ons:**
- Bicycles for local exploration
- Scooter/e-bike for medium distances
- Towing capacity consideration
**Life on Roads vs Trails:**
- "Most of our life is on roads or comfortable trails"
- Prioritize comfort over extreme off-road capability
- Good infrastructure access more important than 4x4
- Save 4x4 adventures for rental overland vehicles
**Long-term Travel Strategy:**
- Focus on reliability for extended trips
- Prefer newer 2x4 over older 4x4 at same price
- For Africa: rent specialized overland vehicle
- Equipment that enables weeks without hookups
**Comfort Features:**
- All modern amenities possible
- Climate control (heating/cooling)
- Full kitchen facilities
- Comfortable sleeping arrangements
- Entertainment systems
- Good insulation

title.en: Carnet de Passages: International Vehicle Documentation for Multi-Year Africa Travel

summary.en: Comprehensive guide to using Carnet de Passages for extended international motorhome travel. Covers validity periods (1 year), renewal procedures for multi-year journeys, and technical regulations for vehicles traveling between countries. Includes solutions for extending coverage beyond initial one-year period and vehicle re-registration procedures.

en: **What is Carnet de Passages:**
- International customs document allowing vehicle entry to countries without local registration
- Issued by auto clubs and customs authorities
- Proves ownership and allows temporary vehicle importation
**Validity Period:**
- Standard validity: 1 year from issuance
- Initial carnet valid for entry to South Africa with northward journey to Kenya
**Key Regulations:**
- Vehicle must return to country of origin within carnet validity period
- No requirement for how long vehicle can stay in foreign countries
- Time restrictions apply to how long vehicle can remain in each country entered with carnet
- Different from vehicle residency rules
**Multi-Year Solutions:**
- After 1 year, exit country where vehicle is located with carnet exit stamp
- Close out expiring carnet with customs exit stamp
- Immediately obtain new carnet for another year of coverage
- Can repeat process for continuous multi-year coverage
**German Carnet Example:**
- German carnets confirmed to support multi-year travel with renewal
- Each renewal requires proper exit stamp before closing
**Weizmann Institute Research Project:**
- Motorhome with research laboratory planned for Africa journey
- Concerns about carnet restrictions led to research consultation
- Need for proper documentation for multi-year African overland travel
**Important Considerations:**
- Consult with import/export specialists familiar with carnet procedures
- Timing of exit stamps critical for renewal process
- Different from Israeli vehicle licensing (which has strict re-export restrictions)
Carnet validity is limited - plan renewal timing carefully
Exit stamps must be obtained before closing carnet
Different countries have different carnet requirements
Israeli vehicles have stricter export restrictions than European vehicles

title.en: LPG Bottle Refilling with Adapter Kit for European Travel

summary.en: Practical guide to using LPG adapter kits for refilling motorhome gas bottles at European gas stations. Covers German gas bottles and refilling at Repsol (Spain) and Avia (France) stations.

en: **Equipment Needed:**
- Standard LPG adapter kit (fits multiple connection types)
- German gas bottle (common in European motorhomes)
**Gas Station Compatibility:**
- Repsol (Spain): Successfully refilled with adapter kit, helpful attendant
- Avia large stations (France): Successful refills with adapter kit and attendant assistance
- Most European stations accept proper adapters
**Refilling Procedure:**
1. Position motorhome at gas station with LPG pump
2. Connect adapter kit to bottle valve
3. Request assistance from attendant if unsure
4. Station attendant can operate pump (recommended for first time)
5. IMPORTANT: Close bottle valve BEFORE disconnecting hose from pump
**Important Safety Note:**
- Close bottle valve before disconnecting from pump
- Failure to do this releases gas pressure (painful experience for some)
- Attendants familiar with procedure and can guide safely
**Tips:**
- Keep adapter kit in vehicle for European travel
- Larger gas stations more likely to assist with refilling
- Attendants are generally helpful and willing to assist
- Second and subsequent refills easier after learning procedure
**Common Issues:**
- Some adapters may not fit German bottles perfectly
- Consult with experienced travelers if unsure of fit
- Ron Kellner can provide technical support and guidance

title.en: Starlink Mini Satellite Internet for Motorhomes: Installation and Performance

summary.en: Practical guide to installing and using Starlink Mini satellite internet on motorhomes for continuous connectivity while traveling. Covers setup, performance metrics, mounting options, and real-world usage during travel.

en: **Equipment & Subscription:**
- Starlink Mini satellite dish
- Subscription: â‚¬49/month (small package)
- Data allowance: 50GB overage (reasonable for motorhome use)
**Initial Setup:**
1. Install outside vehicle for optimal orientation
2. Use Starlink app for simple alignment guidance
3. App provides clear alignment instructions and direction angles
4. First connection: excellent quality (180 Mbps download, 40 Mbps upload)
**Permanent Roof Mount Installation:**
- Mount on motorhome sun roof using vacuum suction mounts
- Vacuum mount system holds very securely
- Good connection through sun roof glass while in vehicle
- Performance slightly reduced vs exterior position but still excellent
- Download: ~110 Mbps, Upload: ~25 Mbps through roof
**Real-World Performance:**
- Continuous connectivity during travel
- Occasional disconnections possible with poor antenna angles (vehicle movement)
- Overall good solution for mobile connectivity
- Works well on roads despite antenna angle changes
**Advantages:**
- No cellular dependency in remote areas
- Works throughout Europe
- Portable and relatively easy to install
- Vacuum mount can move between vehicles
- Works during travel (antenna can catch signal despite movement)
**Practical Considerations:**
- First installation outside vehicle optimizes setup
- Sun roof mounting allows semi-permanent installation
- Performance sufficient for streaming, video calls, web browsing
- Monthly cost reasonable for continuous connectivity
- Data limits should be considered for heavy usage

title.en: Starlink vs Cellular eSIM: European Internet Solutions for Motorhomes

summary.en: Comprehensive comparison of Starlink and cellular eSIM connectivity options for motorhome travel in Europe. Covers EU-wide cellular plans and Starlink subscription options.

en: **Starlink Performance:**
- Excellent coverage most of the time
- Reliable when positioned on roof with clear sky view
- Auto-switches to eSIM backup if connection drops
- Subscription levels: Limited 50GB ($50/month) and Unlimited
- Unlimited plan allows disconnect/reconnect without additional charges
- Better signal when device mounted on roof
- Can pause subscriptions (affects auto-renewal)
- Pause affects auto-renewal but does not refund paid month
- No date extension when paused (proportional billing only)
- Best resumed by pausing 1-2 days before month end
**eSIM Cellular Backup:**
- Auto-switches from Starlink when connection fails
- Keeps fallback internet active for critical needs
- Works alongside Starlink as redundancy
**O2 Germany Prepaid SIM (Recommended):**
- 999GB monthly plan: â‚¬75/month for entire EU
- No auto-renewal: pay for month, get month of service
- Good coverage in remote areas
- Phone number preserved for 1 year without recharge
- Can reload via internet, O2 app, or kiosk/gas station in Germany
- Simple prepaid model: 4 months payment = 4 months service
- No complicated billing cycles
**Starlink Pause/Subscription Management:**
1. Pausing stops monthly billing immediately
2. No refund for already-paid month
3. Months don't extend when paused (proportional billing)
4. Renewal date is set at original signup, not when resuming
5. Best practice: pause 1-2 days before month-end to stop auto-renewal
6. Resumption charge starts on renewal date based on original schedule
7. For extended trips home: pause avoids charges during absence
**Common Starlink Issues in Forested Areas:**
- Tree blockage reduces connection continuity
- Affects voice/video calls more than browsing
- Solution: Reposition antenna via mobile app (usually <1 minute)
- Roof mounting with ball joint improves reliability
**Starlink vs Cellular Comparison:**
- Starlink: Better for continuous browsing and data
- Cellular: Better for voice calls and messaging
- Best: Use both together for redundancy
- O2 prepaid: Simple, no surprise charges, flexible

guides.sharedBy: Ilan, Nirit, Ron Kellner, Boaz Gutman

title.en: Air Conditioning for Motorhomes: Options and Solutions

summary.en: Comprehensive guide to air conditioning solutions for motorhomes, including portable units, rooftop AC, 12V options, and passive cooling strategies.

en: **AC Installation Challenges for Small Motorhomes:**
- Desire to avoid large roof openings
- Limited internal space in 6-meter Ford Transit
- Need for minimal installation impact
**Truck Parking Cab Coolers (Recommended for Minimal Install):**
- 12V options available that fit through skylight openings
- Brands: Indel B, Eberspaecker
- Only requires running wiring from roof skylight
- No major structural modifications needed
- Effective for cab/driver area
**Isolating Blind/Shade Solution (Passive Cooling):**
- Insulated window coverings for front windows
- Significantly helps with extreme weather management
- Zero energy consumption approach
- Recommended by experienced motorhomers
- Effective for both heat and cold management
**Portable AC Units from China (Budget Option):**
- 3000 BTU portable units available on AliExpress (~â‚¬600)
- Requires 220V power (AC inverter needed)
- Only viable with 2000W+ inverter
- Operates primarily when parked with hookups
**Under-Bunk Air Conditioning Units (9000 BTU):**
- Mounted under bench seating (easy installation)
- Requires 220V power supply
- Excellent cooling performance for months of use
- Cons: Limited to when connected to shore power
- Example: Furrion 9000 BTU units from Australia
- Simple piping setup, easy installation
**Roof-Mounted AC Installation:**
- Traditional method with A/C opening in roof
- Initial concerns about structural integrity (but proper installation is safe)
- Used for heating and cooling
- German 'energy-conservative' approach: heat when cold, cool when hot
- Works well for extended trips
**Power Requirements & Inverter Considerations:**
- Installing 1000W inverter is too limiting
- Minimum recommended: 2000W inverter
- Larger inverter allows flexible AC operation
- Battery bank: 200 amp-hour lithium recommended
- Solar system: 305W panel sufficient for basic needs
- AC appliances (kettles) consume more power than expected
**Geographic Strategy (Best Approach):**
- Follow 'chasing 70s' philosophy (70 Fahrenheit/21 Celsius)
- Travel north in summer for cooler weather
- Move south in winter for warmer weather
- Escape extreme temperatures through smart route planning
- Most effective solution vs mechanical cooling
**Mountain Route Alternative:**
- In summer, drive 2-4 hours south from southern France
- Reach mountain areas with excellent cool weather
- Nice outdoor environment even without AC
- More enjoyable than enclosed motorhome in heat
**12V vs 220V Cooling Comparison:**
- 12V truck cab coolers: low power consumption
- 220V portable/under-bunk: more powerful but require hookups
- Consider travel style: on-road vs parked
**Efficiency Mindset (German Cost-Conscious Approach):**
- Not about being stingy, but practical efficiency
- Geographic movement more effective than mechanical cooling
- Route planning key to comfort without excessive power
- Enjoy cooler regions naturally

guides.sharedBy: Ilan, Oren Kipnis, Nadav, Ron Kellner, Tuval Avishi, Efraim Lior, Boaz Gutman, Ravid paz

en: 1000W inverter is too limiting for AC operation
220V AC units need 2000W+ inverter minimum
AC units consume substantial power even on battery
Tree coverage significantly impacts Starlink, less so with cellular

title.en: Carnet de Passage: Vehicle Import Documentation for Africa

summary.en: Guide to obtaining and using Carnet de Passage (ATA Carnet) for temporary vehicle import into Southern Africa. Required for foreign-registered vehicles entering South Africa without permanent import.

en: **What is Carnet de Passage:**
- Official customs document (ATA Carnet) for temporary vehicle import
- Required for foreign-registered vehicles in Southern Africa
- Simplest way to enter and stay in South Africa with a vehicle
- Alternative: Local vehicle registration (complex, time-consuming, not recommended)
**Obtaining Carnet in France:**
- Possible to obtain outside home country (e.g., in France despite registration)
- Process takes time, requires advance planning
- Contact relevant automotive authorities
**Entry into South Africa:**
- Carnet de Passage is the straightforward solution
- With carnet: border crossing is straightforward for vehicle documentation
- Entry by sea: Additional bureaucracy and local agent assistance needed
- Recommend using local agent to handle port paperwork and bureaucracy
**Challenges with Local Registration:**
- Very complex bureaucratic process
- Extremely time-consuming
- Right-hand drive requirement (vehicle with left steering wheel may have restrictions)
- Left-hand drive vehicles: may not be permitted for local registration
- Not recommended approach
**Entry from Sea (Shipping):**
- More bureaucratic than overland entry
- Complex port procedures
- Significant paperwork required
- Professional local agent assistance highly recommended
- Port agent can handle all documentation

notes.en: Critical for anyone planning to ship motorhome to Africa. Carnet solution much simpler than local registration.

title.en: Motorhome Break-In Prevention and Security Measures

summary.en: Critical security guide covering motorhome theft and break-in prevention. Real incidents in Lyon (France) and other locations demonstrate need for secured storage of valuables, documents, and electronics.

en: **Real Break-In Incidents:**
- Lyon, France: Motorhome broken into while tourists visited museum. All documents, clothes stolen. Credit cards fortunately on person.
- Other location: Computer and electronics stolen from street parking in small town.
**Prevention Strategies:**
- Never leave documents in motorhome
- Keep valuables on person when away from vehicle
- Credit cards and passports must travel with you
- Electronics and laptops vulnerable to theft
**Safe Storage Solutions:**
- Install secure safe/lockbox mounted to motorhome floor (attached to chassis)
- Use safes that are difficult to remove quickly
- Safe provides protection against theft AND fire
**Insurance Considerations:**
- Theft from motorhome may be partially covered
- Fire protection benefit of safes important for long-term travel
- Check policy coverage for unattended vehicle break-ins
**Practical Tips:**
- Keep cash, cards, documents on person or hotel safe
- Don't advertise valuable electronics in vehicle
- Park in well-lit, populated areas when possible
- Museum visits, tourist attractions = high theft risk times

title.en: European Motorhome Insurance Costs and Strategies for Non-Residents

summary.en: Comprehensive guide to motorhome insurance in European countries, focusing on costs for non-EU residents, registration strategies, and seasonal insurance options. Covers Germany, France, UK, and Austria.

en: **Germany (Best Value for Non-Residents):**
- Example: 50,000â‚¬ motorhome with German address and plates
- Third party + comprehensive + ADAC membership: 736â‚¬/year (single driver)
- Extended to all drivers: +36â‚¬ (additional 3 months)
- ADAC membership: 94â‚¬/year
- Strategy: Use German address through legal residence declaration
**Seasonal Insurance Germany:**
- Option to insure only 8 months (travel) + 4 months (winter storage)
- German seasonal plates show coverage months
- Costs around 548â‚¬/year for seasonal option
- Vehicle remains covered during storage (fire, theft, break-in)
- German residents get significant no-claims discounts (not available to foreigners)
**France:**
- Insurance quote for Fiat Ducato motorhome (5 years old, 60-65Kâ‚¬ value): 1620â‚¬/year
- Allianz quote described as 'very expensive'
- Recommended: Insure under local French contact if possible
**Austria:**
- Less expensive than France but more than Germany
- Enforcement of local rules strict (police stops after 20:00 hotel arrivals documented)
- Most expensive option documented
- Example: 35-year-old truck motorhome - 3,000 pounds/year
- Previous owner (British with UK license): 300 pounds/year
- Non-resident Israeli premium: 3,000 pounds (+900%)
- Only 1 of 10 insurance companies willing to insure non-residents
- Explicit refusal: Some companies refuse to insure Israelis (discrimination)
**Non-Resident Challenges:**
- No insurance history in EU = no no-claims discounts
- Discounts available to EU residents can reach 30-50%
- Israeli insurance history not accepted by European insurers
- Some companies discriminate based on nationality
**Strategies for Non-EU Residents:**
1. Register under local contact (Germany best option) - legal if residence declared
2. Local registrant becomes registered owner (teacher, government worker status helps)
3. Seasonal insurance for winter storage saves significant costs
4. ADAC (Germany) offers best rates for non-residents with legal address
5. Germany seasonal plates required for seasonal insurance
**Cost Comparisons (Same vehicle, ~50Kâ‚¬ value):**
- Germany: 736â‚¬/year (best)
- France: 1,620â‚¬/year (expensive)
- UK: 3,000 pounds (most expensive)
- Austria: Middle range
**Additional Notes:**
- Vehicle coverage types: Third party (liability) + Comprehensive
- All countries require at minimum Third Party (liability) insurance
- Comprehensive covers theft, fire, accidents, collision
- Storage coverage: Usually included for stationary vehicles

title.en: Starlink Mini Satellite Internet: Temperature Limitations and Performance

summary.en: Technical guide to Starlink Mini satellite internet equipment used by motorhome travelers. Covers critical temperature limitation (50Â°C max), performance implications for hot climates like Italy.

en: **Temperature Limitation (Critical):**
- Maximum operating temperature: 50Â°C (122Â°F)
- When exceeded, device disconnects automatically
- Error message: 'Will reconnect when device cools down'
**Impact for Hot Climate Travel:**
- Italy summer temperatures regularly exceed 50Â°C inside motorhomes
- Mediterranean region may experience frequent disconnections
- Device throttles performance at high temperatures
- Users should plan for significant disconnection periods during hot days
**Mitigation Strategies:**
- Keep device in shaded areas
- Provide adequate ventilation
- Consider additional cooling during hot months
- Schedule critical internet tasks for cooler morning/evening hours
- May need to reduce or pause travel during peak heat months
**Performance Notes:**
- Works well in cooler climates and seasons
- Not suitable for unmanaged outdoor exposure to sun
- Needs careful placement in motorhome
**Recommendation:**
Starlink Mini works well for mobile internet in Europe, but users in hot climates must account for significant operational downtime during hot weather.

title.en: Family Motorhome Travel with Teenagers: Space, Privacy, and Logistics

summary.en: Guide for families traveling with teenagers in motorhomes, addressing space constraints, privacy needs, sleeping arrangements, and adapting living space for different ages and developmental stages.

en: **Challenge: Teenager Space Requirements:**
- Teenagers need personal space and privacy
- Limited motorhome square footage creates conflicts
- Example: Family with ages 13, 16+ (rapidly growing)
**Sleeping Solutions Tested:**
**Previous Configuration (worked moderately):**
- Three older daughters: shared bed above driver's area
- Son (14): Built custom bed over dining table (conserves folding)
- Advantage: Avoids nightly table setup/teardown
- Limitation: Reduced daytime dining/living space
**Current Configuration (improved privacy):**
- Dining table converts to bed each evening (traditional approach)
- Provides flexibility but requires nightly setup/teardown
- Better daytime space utilization
- Allows more separation of sleeping areas
**Strategies for Managing Teens:**
1. **Outdoor Time Strategy:** Summer encourages outdoor activities
- Move social interactions to outdoor spaces
- Quiet personal time still available in motorhome if needed
- Reduce indoor crowding naturally
2. **Personal Space Zones:**
- Designate individual 'areas' within motorhome
- Different sleeping spots for different family members
- Use separate outdoor seating/camping areas
3. **Sleeping Arrangement Flexibility:**
- Alternative: Small tents outside motorhome (example from Sylvie)
- Quick setup (10 minutes) and takedown
- Works even in rain
- Provides complete privacy option
4. **Daytime Logistics:**
- Encourage outdoor exploration and activities
- Local parks, hiking, beaches for teen activities
- Separate adult/teen quiet times
**Family Testimonial:**
Father of teens observed: 'The biggest help is encouraging them outdoors. Most of our time is outside or on comfortable trails. This naturally creates the quiet and personal space they need.'
**Packing Considerations:**
- Bring quick-setup tents (10-minute assembly)
- Plan outdoor activities for hot weather months
- Flexible sleeping options reduce nightly conflicts
**Success Tips:**
- Reframe trip as adventure (not confinement)
- Leverage outdoor activities for natural spacing
- Accept some compromise on personal space
- Teenagers may remember freedom and exploration positively

title.en: GPS Navigation for Motorhomes: App Comparison and Vehicle-Aware Routing

summary.en: Comprehensive comparison of GPS navigation applications suitable for motorhomes and large vehicles including Sygic Track, OsmAnd+, and CoPilot. Focuses on vehicle-aware routing that prevents drivers from entering inappropriate roads based on vehicle dimensions (height, width, weight).

en: **Sygic Track (Specialized for Motorhomes/Trucks):**
- Input vehicle dimensions: height, width, weight
- Prevents entering unsuitable roads
- Premium version: â‚¬30/year
- Shows bridge heights, road restrictions, weight limits
- Supports Android Auto
**Issues and Limitations:**
- Map accuracy varies by country (excellent in UK, chaotic in Germany)
- App can still send drivers under too-low bridges despite updates
- Navigation icons can obscure map and nearby environment
- U-turn instructions sometimes incorrect (says left/right when should go straight)
- U-turn maneuvers extremely difficult on narrow 8.5m roads
- After 2+ months in 6 countries, app became frustrating for experienced users
**OsmAnd+ (Open Source Alternative):**
- Free/Open source navigation app
- Vehicle profile support: weight, height, width
- Works with Android Auto
- Less developed than commercial options
- Better for those willing to learn alternative interface
**CoPilot (Premium Alternative):**
- Includes vehicle dimensions input (height, width, weight)
- Prevents problematic road entries
- Premium version: â‚¬30/year
- User reports: app helped avoid problematic routes
**Setup Recommendations:**
- Enter exact vehicle dimensions (height, width, weight)
- Test navigation before major journeys
- Consider bridge clearance even with GPS help
- Be prepared to manually override when needed
**Real User Experience:**
- One user reported bridge scenario: declared 2.7m bridge with 2.5m width excluding mirrors/accessories
- Another: GPS calculated exactly but driver needed extra caution at boundaries
**Best Practices:**
- Sygic Track most developed for vehicle-specific routing
- OsmAnd+ best for open-source enthusiasts
- CoPilot good middle ground at reasonable cost
- Always visual verification recommended for tight clearances
- Follow community recommendations for your specific region

Vehicle dimensions must be entered correctly - including mirrors and accessories
Apps can still make errors - never blindly trust GPS for bridge or road clearances
U-turn algorithms problematic on narrow roads

title.en: ADAC Membership Benefits for European Motorhome Travel

title.en: Air Conditioning in Motorhomes: What Works and What Doesn't

summary.en: Practical guide distinguishing between ineffective small portable AC units and functional climate control solutions for motorhomes. Includes real user experiences with different AC sizes, ventilation strategies, and cost-benefit analysis.

en: **Small Portable AC Units (3000 BTU - Do NOT Buy):**
- Intended for tents, not motorhomes
- Only 3000 BTU cooling capacity
- Requires external window hose (loses energy)
- Energy inefficiency very high relative to cooling output
- Marketed via AliExpress: attractive but ineffective
**Why Small AC Fails in Motorhomes:**
- 6-meter motorhome needs much more capacity
- 1 HP (Tornado) AC units barely cool ~10 mÂ² in hot days
- Even 7000 BTU units (Dometic) marginal for full motorhome
- 3000 BTU units: completely insufficient
**What ACTUALLY Works:**
- Proper sized AC unit (minimum 7000-9000 BTU for typical motorhome)
- Multiple small, powerful fans distributed throughout
- Creates air circulation and reasonable cooling
- More efficient than undersized AC
- Lower power consumption than large AC systems
**Real User Experiences:**
- User A: 'Tested small portable AC, useless except as footrest'
- User B: 'Tornado 1HP AC works hard even in ~10mÂ² space, useless at night'
- User C: 'Dometic 7000 BTU barely sufficient even at maximum'
**Alternative Approach - Door Insulation:**
- Found that motorhome doors are primary heat loss point
- Door: standard product sold in most camper stores
- Solution: Add foam insulation layer to door interior (like yoga mat)
- Result: Measurable improvement in temperature efficiency
- Combined with AC, becomes much more effective
**Heating System Note:**
- Heating is very effective in motorhomes
- Even small diesel heaters can warm entire vehicle
- Night heating at 11Â°C outside: works excellently
**Energy Consumption Reality:**
- Small portable ACs consume disproportionate power
- For off-grid living, power budget becomes critical constraint
- Better to accept some heat and use fans
- Or invest in oversized solar + battery for full AC capability
**Recommendations:**
- Skip 3000-5000 BTU units entirely
- For on-grid: invest in proper 9000+ BTU AC
- For off-grid: use fan strategy + selective AC time
- For insulation: prioritize door sealing first
- Combine thermal imaging to find other heat loss points

title.en: European Vehicle Registration Requirements for Extended Travel

summary.en: Guide to vehicle registration, annual testing requirements, and insurance considerations for motorhome travelers planning extended stays outside their home country. Covers Germany, France, and transit procedures.

en: **Annual Testing Requirements:**
- Germany and France: Every 2 years for vehicles up to 3.5 tons
- Vehicles over 3.5 tons: Annual testing required
- Testing required for insurance validity (no official confirmation but standard practice)
**Extended Travel Without Testing:**
- If vehicle is registered in Germany or France and you leave the country, testing not required until re-entry
- Transit number (ZOLL/TRANSIT) allows temporary vehicle export
**ZOLL/TRANSIT Number Implications:**
- ZOLL (now called TRANSIT) number is designed for temporary exports
- Requires export documentation and customs paperwork when leaving Europe
- Upon return, requires vehicle import process and potentially taxes
- Not recommended if planning to return to Europe regularly
- Better option: Register in Germany or France if planning extended European travel
**Registration in Germany or France:**
- German registration allows 7+ years of European travel without testing while outside Germany
- French registration allows similar flexibility
- Requires AXA travel insurance (Schengen) annually
- Insurance auto-renews even when vehicle is outside Europe if continuity maintained
- Only requirement: Testing when re-entering your registration country
**Insurance Coverage Abroad:**
- Minimum mandatory insurance at border crossings outside Europe
- Optional: AXA Schengen or equivalent European travel insurance
- Insurance auto-renewal possible with proper documentation
- Alternative insurance arrangements may be needed in remote areas
**Real-World Example:**
- 5+ years of travel outside Europe with German-registered vehicle
- No testing performed during entire period
- Insurance maintained with minimal documentation
- Upon return to Europe, testing and re-registration required
**Practical Recommendations:**
- Plan registration location based on travel duration
- If staying in Europe 6+ months yearly: German or French registration preferred
- If doing global overland: Consider ZOLL/TRANSIT but plan export/import carefully
- Always carry proof of insurance at border crossings
